passage.text: Reactivity of natural organic matter with aqueous chlorine and bromine
Relevant resource
True|False
Abstract

While both aqueous bromine (HOBr/OBr−) and chlorine (HOCl/OCl−) react with natural organic matter (NOM) during water treatment, limited direct parallel comparison of bromine versus chlorine has been conducted. Experiments with model compounds and natural waters indicated more efficient substitution reactions with bromine than chlorine. Kinetic experiments with NOM isolates with and without pre-ozonation were conducted to obtain second-order rate constants (k) with bromine and chlorine. Two-stage reaction kinetics (rapid initial and slower consumption stages) were observed. Bromine reacted about 10 times faster than chlorine with NOM isolates during both stages. The rapid initial stage reactions were too fast to quantify k values, but qualitative estimates ranged between 500 and 5000 M−1 s−1. For the slower second stage k values for bromine were 15 to 167 M−1 s−1 over the pH range of 5–11, and lower for chlorine (k = 0.7–5 M−1 s−1). Values of k correlated with initial SUVA values of NOM (UVA measured at 254 nm divided by DOC). Based upon UV/VIS and solid-state 13C-NMR spectroscopy, chlorine addition to a NOM isolate resulted in significant oxidation of aromatic and ketone groups while bromine had significantly less change in spectra. Overall, the improved knowledge that bromine reacts faster and substitutes more efficiently than chlorine will be useful in developing strategies to control disinfection by-product formation during water treatment.

keywords
['Bromine', 'Chlorine', 'Water treatment', 'Natural organic matter', '1']
Introduction

Disinfection by-products (DBPs) form during oxidation/disinfection of waters containing natural organic matter (NOM) and bromide ions (Br−), which both exist ubiquitously in drinking water sources NOM reactions with halogens (e.g., aqueous chlorine, bromine, and iodine) have been reported to react via oxidation (i.e., cleaving carbon–carbon double bonds) and/or substitution (i.e., replacement of functional groups by a halogen molecule) (1) Br − + O 3 → OBr − + O 2 , k 1 =160 M −1 s −1 , (2) Br − + HOCl → HOBr + Cl − , k 2 =2950 M −1 s −1 . Reactions between chlorine and model organic compounds or NOM have shown that aromatic compounds (e.g., phenols, aromatic amino acids) produce regulated DBPs NOM consists of a heterogeneous mixture of humic substances, hydrophilic acids, protein, lipids, carbohydrates, carboxylic acid, amino acid, and hydrocarbons The literature lacks sufficient direct comparisons between bromine versus chlorine reactivity with NOM. While it is generally accepted that bromine reacts faster than chlorine with NOM, little direct evidence of these reactions exist. For example, hypobromite was found to be a more complete oxidant and a faster substituting agent than hypochlorite with resorcinol and its derivatives 2
Materials and methods
Materials

All reagents and chemicals were analytical grade. Eight model organic compounds that represent potential DBP precursors were used ( ). The solutions were prepared with water (∼18.3 MΩ) made from an ultrapure water system (Nanopure InfinityTM). Phosphoric acid (H3PO4) and sodium hydroxide (NaOH) were used for pH adjustment. Solutions containing NOM were prepared using lyophilized organic material. Experiments with isolated NOM permitted 13C-NMR analysis of directly lyophilized samples, without re-fractionation on resins, before and after exposure to oxidants (aqueous bromine and chlorine). A reverse osmosis isolated sample from Suwannee River (SR-RO) was purchased from the International Humic Substance Society. A second NOM isolate was obtained from Colorado River Water (CRW) by nanofiltration concentration and resin adsorption. Briefly, the second isolation included the following sequential steps: (1) prefiltration (Whatman glass fiber filters, 100-25DH and 100-25AH), (2) softening with sodium exchangeable resin (Barnstead-Thermoclyne D8904), (3) recirculating preconcentration with a 500 Da nanofilter (NF-70), (4) acidification to pH 2 and loading (k′=5) onto XAD-4 resin (Amberlite), (5) elution with 75% acetonitrile/25%water, (6) roto-evaporation, (7) lyophilization. The isolation method recovered approximately 80% of the initial organic carbon. For select experiments pre-ozonated NOM solutions were used. Pre-ozonation was conducted by apply gaseous ozone to samples (DOC=3.2 mg/L) for 5 min, followed by helium purging of residual dissolved ozone. The purpose of pre-ozonation was to oxidize some of the NOM sites prior to addition of aqueous chlorine or bromine. The aqueous chlorine stock solution was prepared from sodium hypochlorite (FisherTM, 13% active), whereas aqueous bromine stock solution was prepared from pure liquid bromine (Aldrich, 99.9%). 2.2
Experimental approach
Halogen consumption and haloform production (Approach I)

Experiments were designed to compare the haloform substitution efficiency of aqueous bromine and chlorine with model organic compounds and in a coagulated water. Solutions of model organic chemicals ( ) were prepared and adjusted to a pH of 7.5 with 1 mM phosphate buffer. Alum coagulation was conducted in a jar testing apparatus with CRW. Bromine or chlorine was added, separately, to samples (model compound or coagulated water) in 40 mL amber vials with Teflon caps. The halogen dose was selected at 2 mol halogen per mole carbon in the model compounds, thus the conditions would be comparable to those in solutions with NOM where chlorine is dosed based upon a DOC concentration. Residual halogen concentrations were measured after 40 min, and in a duplicate vial the halogen residual was quenched sodium thiosulfate. Within 24 h the quenched samples was analyzed for THMs. The THM results represent measurement of a single sample. 2.2.2
Rate constants (Approach II)

Batch kinetic experiments were conducted to obtain second-order rate constants for the reaction between bromine or chlorine with NOM isolates (SR-RO & CRW), including preozonated NOM isolates. Aqueous bromine or chlorine was added separately to solutions containing different sources and concentrations of NOM in a completely mixed reactor (500-mL amber repipetting glass-bottle dispenser on a magnetic stir plate). Pseudo-first-order conditions (excess NOM) were assumed. A 2 μM concentration of bromine or chlorine was added, separately, to samples with initial NOM concentrations ranging from 0 to 150 μM (assuming a carbon molecular weight of 12 g/mol). Residual aqueous bromine or chlorine concentrations were monitored over time. Pseudo-first-order rate constants with respect to aqueous bromine and chlorine were calculated for each NOM concentration and used to obtain second-order rate constants (M−1 s−1). Most experiments were conducted at pH 5 and 24°C. Additional experiments were also conducted at different pH values (pH 8 and 11) and a lower temperature at 10°C. 2.2.3
Effect of oxidants on NOM structure (Approach III)

Experiments were designed to compare how bromine and chlorine changed the structure of NOM. Batch experiments with SR-RO were conducted at pH 7. 13C-NMR spectra were compared for samples exposed to bromine or chlorine against a control (no oxidant added). A halogen dose of approximately 0.14 mmol of chlorine or bromine was applied per mg DOC. After reacting for 14 days at 22°C in the dark, the samples were acidified with HCl to pH 2.2 and sparged with nitrogen to remove residual halogen. Samples were lyophilized and analyzed by solid-state 13C-NMR, and dissolved in ultrapure water prior to ultra/visible (UV/VIS) spectrophotometic analysis. 2.3
Analytical methods

For experiments in Approach I and III, aqueous bromine and chlorine concentrations were measured by the colorimetric N,N Diethyl-P-Phenylenediamine (DPD) method A multi-wavelength UV/VIS spectrophotometer (Shamdzu UV-160U) with a 1-cm cell pathlength was used to measure the UV absorbance of DOC at wavelength range from 250 to 280 nm and ABTS at 405 nm. DOC concentrations were determined using a catalytic-thermal combustion method with infrared gas analysis (Shimadzu TOC 5050A Analyzer). Specific UV absorbance (SUVA) was determined by normalizing UVA to DOC concentration (UVA/DOC) 3
Results
Halogen consumption and haloform production

For the model compounds, less chlorine and bromine was consumed after 40 min in the reaction with maleic acid than with other benzene-substituted compounds ( ). Resorcinol, which contains two hydroxyl functional groups (–OH), had the largest halogen consumption. Benzoic acid and analine consumed more chlorine than bromine, while except for phenol the other substituted benzenes consumed similar amounts of bromine and chlorine. Haloform (CHX3) production was measured in parallel with the halogen consumption experiments for the same 40-min reaction period ( ). CHX3 production per mole of organic compound ranged from approximately 0.001 mol/mol for maleic and benzoic acid to 0.1 mol/mol for resorcinol. Bromoform (CHBr3) production upon bromine addition was higher than CHCl3 production upon chlorine addition for all model compounds except maleic acid and resorcinol. For two different model compounds replicates had low standard deviations (<5%) for both halogen consumption and haloform production (not shown). Furthermore, for nearly identical conditions as a previous study with a subset of model compounds and chlorine, the halogen consumption and haloform production after 40 min were comparable ( —data from Norwood et al. Oxidation experiments using a 40 min contact time were also conducted with raw and alum coagulated (25–225 mg/L) CRW. Simulated alum coagulation removed 5% of the DOC at 25 mg/L of alum and over 40% of the DOC for alum dosages above 150 mg/L. Increasing alum dosages lowered the water pH and decreased both DOC and UV absorbance (data not shown). Filtered aliquots from the jar tests were pH adjusted to 7.5 and then spiked (0.3 mM) with either bromine or chlorine. Halogen consumption and haloform production are reported in . For parallel experiments a higher molar concentration of bromoform was produced after bromine addition than chloroform produced after chlorine addition. The haloform substitution efficiency (CHX3 produced per mole X2 consumed) was always greater for bromine than chlorine. The ratio of bromine to chlorine haloform substitution efficiencies increased from 2.5 after 25 mg/L of alum to 5.4, 5.9, and 7.1 after alum dosages of 100, 150, and 200 mg/L, respectively. Thus, alum coagulation of CRW resulted in organic matrix more susceptible to bromine substitution into THMs than to chlorine substitution into THMs. Coagulation preferentially removed organic materials capable of forming haloforms in the presence of chlorine. 3.2
NOM and aqueous bromine or chlorine rate constants

Bromine reacted with NOM isolates on the order of seconds, whereas chlorine reactions were on a timescale of minutes ( ). Halogen consumption exhibited two reaction stages: (1) rapid initial consumption followed by (2) slower consumption. The cross-over between reaction stages occurred over 1–5 min for chlorine and <15 s for bromine. This initial halogen consumption was not caused by halogen reactions with trace inorganics in solution or the glassware. Control experiments (no NOM) showed only a small initial halogen consumption (<5% of halogen dose). Therefore, the high initial halogen demand in experiments containing NOM was likely associated with highly reactive organic matter sites. The rate of aqueous chlorine or bromine consumption increased with higher initial DOC concentrations (from 0 to 150 μM). For example, presents results from kinetic experiments using aqueous bromine and the CRW isolate at a range of DOC concentrations (pH=5). Pseudo-first-order analysis of the data for the second reaction stage (⩾20 s) is presented; rate constants are indicated as the slope of the linear regression through data in . Both the rapid initial consumption (<15 s) and slower consumption reaction stages (⩾20 s) exhibited rate constants that were larger at higher DOC concentrations. Halogen consumption during the rapid initial stage was greater for the SR-RO isolate than CRW isolate, and was a function of DOC concentration. Due to fast reaction rates during the rapid initial consumption stage, rate constants could only be estimated from pseudo-zero-order calculations using the observed data (e.g., change in halogen concentration: Δbromine15 s and Δchlorine5 min; ). In comparison with chlorine, very rapid reactions between bromine and the NOM isolates resulted in rate constants that are approximately 1–2 orders of magnitude higher than resulting from chlorine. Pre-ozonation of NOM isolates decreased the initial halogen consumption by approximately 30%–40%. For the slower halogen consumption stage, pseudo-first-order rate constants (k′; s−1) were calculated from data plotted similar to . The following pseudo-first-order and second-order reaction rates were considered: r= d [ HOBr ] d t =−k′[ HOBr ]=k[ NOM ][ HOBr ], where k′=k [NOM] and k is a second-order rate constant (M−1 s−1). illustrates a plot of k′ values for different initial DOC concentrations obtained in the presence of bromine and CRW or SR-RO isolates. The slope from linear analysis of data in yields a second-order rate constant (k). Values of k for bromine and the SR-RO isolate (130 M−1 s−1 at pH 5) were four times higher than for the CRW isolate (30 M−1 s−1 at pH 5). summarizes k values from experiments (pH=5) with different NOM isolates, halogens, and temperature. All experiments were conducted under similar halogen and DOC concentrations. Values of k for either aqueous chlorine or bromine were three to five times higher for the SR-RO isolate than the CRW isolate. Pre-ozonation of each isolate reduced the k value by approximately 50%. The k value for bromine was approximately 18 times higher than the chlorine k value for the CRW isolate, and 31 times higher for the SR-RO isolate. Temperature effects on the k values were minimal between 10°C and 24°C. Experiments with the SR-RO isolate (no pre-ozonation) were conducted at pH 5, 8, and 11. k values for bromine (kHOBr) and the SR-RO isolate at pH 5, 8, and 11 were 130, 167, and 124 M−1 s−1, respectively, and were 4.8, 2.4, and 3.2 M−1 s−1, respectively, for chlorine (kHOCl). The lack of a high variability in k values over the pH range between 5 and 11 precluded further consideration of effects from halogen or NOM functional group dissociation. 3.3
Effects of bromine and chlorine on UV/VIS and 13C-NMR spectra

UV absorbance in the range of 250–280 nm is an indicator of sp2-hybridized carbon (e.g., aromatic carbon) ). The inset of shows the UV/VIS spectra for SR-RO isolate (non-oxidized DOC=1 mg/L) prior to halogen addition. A positive value for the differential spectra across wavelengths from 250 to 500 nm indicates a decrease in absorbance at a specific wavelength. Chlorine addition resulted in higher differential UV/VIS absorbance values than bromine addition. The largest difference in absorbance from the non-oxidized SR-RO spectra occurred at 260 nm with a 48% reduction in absorbance upon chlorine addition and only an 8% decrease upon bromine addition. Pre-ozonation decreased UV absorbance at 260 nm by ∼45%, similar to the change induced during chlorination. Solid-state 13C-NMR spectra for three different SR-RO isolates (non-oxidized, brominated, and chlorinated) are presented in . The spectra from duplicate solid-state 13C-NMR experiments were nearly identical, and were used to confirm the results. The non-oxidized SR-RO sample, that had been pH adjusted in similar fashions as the brominated and chlorinated samples, had a solid-state 13C-NMR spectra typical of a sample dominated by humic and fulvic acid material and was characterized by a relatively large amount of material in the aromatic region (110–160 ppm). While NMR spectra for humic and fulvic acids isolated from the Suwannee River have been extensively characterized, this is among the first solid-state 13C-NMR for the RO isolate. summarizes the percentage of response area within specific shift wavelength regions of the 13C-NMR spectra that are indicative of certain carbon bonding and functional group arrangements. also presents 13C-NMR data for the CRW isolate, which had less aromatic carbon and more aliphatic carbon than the SR-RO isolate. The lower aromatic carbon content of the CRW isolate (SUVA=1.3 m−1 (mgDOC/L)−1), in comparison with the SR-RO isolate (SUVA=4.2 m−1 (mgDOC/L)−1), is consistent with differences in SUVA. Solid-state 13C-NMR spectra after chlorination or bromination are included with the non-oxidized SR-RO isolate in . The lower portion of shows differential 13C-NMR spectra upon halogen addition, relative to the non-oxidized SR-RO isolate where spectra response regions that clearly deviate from background signal to noise can be distinguished. Both chlorine and bromine addition decreased spectra response between 0 and 60 ppm (aliphatic carbon range) and 100 to 160 ppm (aromatic carbon range). A decrease in the anomeric range (90–110 ppm) was not distinctively evident. Chlorination also resulted in a near elimination of spectra response between 190 and 220 ppm (ketones). Spectra responses were unchanged within 60–90 ppm range (aliphatic carbon bonded with an oxygen atom) or 160–190 ppm (carboxyl carbon) range. In general, chlorination resulted in a much more significant change in the 13C-NMR spectrum of SR-RO than bromination. Since the solid-state 13C-NMR analytical method employed cross polarization to protons, it was possible that a portion of the reduced spectra response was due to halogen substitution into organic matter at sites where protons would have otherwise been located. This may have been a primary factor in the reduced response for the aliphatic carbon region from 0 to 60 ppm, where primary carbon bound with bromine (20–40 ppm) or chlorine (25–50 ppm) would be detected. However, chlorine addition, and to a significantly lesser extent bromine addition, appeared to significantly affect the aromatic carbon region. 4
Discussion

Reaction mechanisms between halogens and NOM include substitution into NOM producing organic halides and oxidation of carbon bonds. HOCl (E red 0 =+1.630 V) has a higher redox potential than HOBr (E red 0 =+1.331 V) . However, the activities of electrophilic (aromatic) substitution for electron release to stabilize carbocation are more favorable for the Br atom due to its higher electron density and smaller bond strength relative to the Cl atom. Chlorine and bromine consumption by model compounds varied depending on their characteristics, but generally a stronger electron donating functional group resulted in an increase in the rate of reaction. Compounds with hydroxyl (−OH) functional groups had both high halogen consumption and haloform formation, whereas compounds attach with carboxy (−COOH) functional groups had lower halogen consumption and haloform formation. Based upon the comparison of bromoform to chloroform yields, aqueous bromine is a more effective substituting halogen than aqueous chlorine. The largest differential 13C-NMR ranges were 100–120 and 140–160 ppm ( ). These shift ranges corresponds with di-hydroxy-benzoic acids that have high reactivity towards chlorine The above findings may compliment work using differential UV spectroscopy as a surrogate tool for predicting organic halide formation Kinetic studies showed that k values for bromine were 15–167 M−1 s−1 over the pH range of 5–11, and lower for chlorine (k=0.7 to 5 M−1 s−1). Kinetic reactions indicated that the rate of bromine reaction with NOM is approximately an order of magnitude higher than chlorine in a pH range between 5 and 11. Other work observed from plots of bromine to chlorine present in THMs as a function of [Br−]:[chlorine] ratio an apparent overall ratio for second-order rate constants of bromine (kb) to chlorine (kc) had a mean value (kb/kc) of approximately 9 and indicate bromine substitution with model and natural organic compounds is greater than chlorine substitution by one order of magnitude, and supports the order of magnitude observations for kb/kc from Over the pH range of 5–11, k values for halogen reactions with NOM varied by less than a factor of ten. In contrast, second-order rate constant values for deprotonated phenols exhibited a maximum value around pH 8 that was 100 to 1000 times greater than at pH 4 or 12 Both k′ for the faster reaction stage ( ) and k for the slower reaction stage ( ) values were linearly correlated (R2>0.9) with initial SUVA of un-ozonated and pre-ozonated CRW (1.3 and 0.8 m−1 [mg/L]−1) and SR-RO (4.2 and 2.4 m−1[mg/L]−1) isolates, respectively. Correlations between initial SUVA and k values for un-ozonated NOM are presented in . Relationships between both k′ and k are noteworthy and imply that the initial NOM structure contained sp2-hybridized carbon bonds that were reactive with oxidants. Evidence from the model compound work could suggest that some of these carbons may also have been bonded with electron donating functional groups (i.e., amine or hydroxyl), resulting in faster reacting NOM “sites” characterized by k′ values. Other sp2-hybridized carbon bonds may have contained electron withdrawing functional groups (i.e., carboxyl) that resulted in slower reacting NOM “sites” as represented by those quantified by k values. Previous work investigated the relative rate of bromine reaction with NOM isolates and kinetics of total organo-bromine (TOBr) formation . The average rate of change in bromine over the first 2 min of reaction was 1.5×10−7 M s−1 and during the second slower stage had a pseudo-first-order rate constant of 0.4×10−3 s−1 . Much higher bromine dosages were used by The CRW isolate had a lower SUVA, less aromatic carbon, and lower k value for the halogens than the SR-RO isolate. Pre-ozonation has previously been shown to selectively oxidize aromatic moieties and produce oxygenated by-products such as ketones and anomeric carbon Alum coagulation reduced SUVA and led to lower haloform production ( ). Chlorine consumption was only lowered by 10–20% after coagulation, but chloroform production decreased by >60%. Thus the chlorine haloform substitution efficiency was reduced after alum coagulation. In contrast, bromine substitution efficiencies decreased by less than 20% after alum coagulation, as both bromine consumption and bromoform production decreased by similar amounts. Overall, bromine haloform substitution efficiency was approximately ten times higher than chlorine haloform substitution efficiency. 5
Conclusions

Brominated organics produced during chlorination of natural waters are due to the oxidation of ambient bromide to form HOBr/OBr−, followed by the incorporation of bromine and chlorine, simultaneously, into precursor organic compounds. Since aqueous bromine reactions with NOM are much faster than aqueous chlorine, the speciation and concentrations of DBP formation in chlorination processes are mainly dominated by the ratio of bromide to reactive NOM as well as the ratio of bromide to chlorine concentrations. During chlorination of waters containing bromide, the typical molar ratio of applied chlorine to the ambient concentration of Br− is approximately on the order of 10. Therefore, this could explain why chlorine and bromine reactions are very competitive during the chlorination process where a mixed composition of halogenated DBPs is produced. The balance between elevated Cl-concentrations and its slower observed rate of reaction determines the overall composition of halogenated DBPs during chlorination. The goal of this study is to compare the selectivity of reaction and haloform substitution efficiency for aqueous bromine against aqueous chlorine in reactions with NOM. The following conclusions were obtained from the study: • From experiments with model organic compounds it was concluded that aromatics had higher halogen consumption and more efficient halogen substitution than aliphatics in general, although the presence of carboxy and/or methoxy functional groups on benzene rings resulted in similar reactivity as a simple aliphatic (maleic acid). Thus the distribution of organic functional groups and carbon bonding in NOM will influence its reactivity with halogens. • Aqueous bromine reactions with NOM were faster than corresponding aqueous chlorine reactions by approximately a factor of ten. Both oxidants exhibited rapid initial and slower secondary halogen consumption stages. Calculated rate constants were proportional to the initial SUVA of the NOM. • Aqueous bromine substituted into organic structures, whereas aqueous chlorine tended to cleave carbon bonds and have a more significant impact on NOM structure based upon UV/VIS and solid-state 13C-NMR spectroscopy. • Pre-ozonation or alum coagulation reduced the rate of reaction between halogens and NOM, but had less effect on aqueous bromine than chlorine substitution efficiencies with NOM. These conclusions support the hypothesis that aqueous bromine is a better substituting agent in general than chlorine, which acts more as an oxidant than bromine. The implication of this work is that order of magnitude estimates for rate constants between NOM and chlorine or bromine are now available, and can be used in conjunction with rate constants for model organic compounds. Observed bromine rate constants are approximately 10 times higher than chlorine rate constants. This can be useful in predicting the cycling and fate of bromide during chlorination. For instance, in previous work it was observed that approximately 10% of bromine reacted with NOM and formed brominated organics, while the remaining 90% was reduced to bromide . In the presence of chlorine, reduced bromide will be oxidized to bromine and available for additional reactions and resulting in bromide-bromine cycling. Given the potential health effects associated with brominated organics, addition research effort should focus on the by-products of bromine reactions with NOM in the absence of chlorine or other oxidants (e.g., ozone).
